data.title: Refuse files with UTF-8 BOM via git-hook or Travis
data.body:
Example implementation:

Note that OS X's `head` uses `-c n` while (I believe) Ubuntu's uses `--bytes=n`.

``` bash
#!/bin/sh

utf8_bom=$(printf "\xEF\xBB\xBF");
bomfiles=$(
    find . -not -iwholename "*.git*" -type f |
    while read filename ; do
        if [ $(head -c 3 "$filename") = $utf8_bom ] ; then
            echo "$filename"
        fi
    done
);

if [ -n "$bomfiles" ] ; then
    echo "The following files have UTF-8 BOM:"
    echo "$bomfiles"
        echo "\nCommit rejected."
    exit 1
fi

exit 0
```

data.title: Allowed turrets to randomly realign when idle.
data.body: This should also fix the popup turrets.

data.title: LUA: make it possible to sell structures
data.body:
original single player TD AI when cornered would often sell its buildings

it took a bit of fun from the game if one loses targets that way, but if selling is possible the AI opponent could sell in a fraction of endgames, making AI less predictable

other instances where this may be useful:
- AI does no longer have construction yard and refinery and needs money: sell silos
- AI does no longer have harvester and no means (building or money) to build one: sell refinery
- AI has no longer enough power for Obelisk or Advanced Guard Tower and no construction yard to build powerplant: sell useless defense structures

related to #9164

data.title: LUA: make it possible to build structures
data.body:
Barracks.Build({"e1"}) works but Yard.Build({"pyle"}) doesn't seem to do anything. LUA api only mentions "actors" as a result of Build() so I think placing structures is not currently supported

Telling the AI to build structures would be useful to make the AI rebuild its base in TD single-player missions

Additional things to consider:
- tell the AI where to build (i.e. in missions, rebuild at site of previously destroyed building)
- if that does not work (actor occupying that space on the map), build where it is possible instead as long as it is in the build radius of the construction yard

data.title: ActorInit.GetInitKeys is unused.
Add PlugInit
data.body:
Add `PlugInit` for use with map-placed structures in TS (or whatever custom mod decides to use plugs). There have been a couple of requests by people who wanted to have plugs on their maps.
I also figured I should use this to make the towers on the new TS shellmap look better.

data.title: Bleed - Can target & attack cloaked buildings
data.body:
See also #8899.

In TS, buildings protected by a Nod stealth gen get an attack cursor when you mouse over them and can be attacked. #9090 will prevent the tooltips appearing, but not prevent attacks.

A quick test shows this also affects camo pillboxes in RA, but not subs - so it seems to be building related.

data.title: Silo fix
data.body:
The normal ore silo is currently not worth of building. I think that common sense.
pro players don't buiild them and even joke about them, cause silos don't give a significant advantage. But in my Opinion they hold great potential, in combinations with the engineers and the spies.
They should get a fix.

For example lower the ore what the refinery can stock, to make silos more needed.
The silos should get an alternativ weakpoint in my opinion. Splitting the potential of attacking the economy in two. Incomming ore (refineries + harvesters), and the ore stock (silos + refineries).

Instead of sniping a refinery it should be more worth it to snipe the silos.

data.title: Mini-map/radar not showing enemy structures under fog of war
data.body:
(playtest 20150808)
Let's say you scout an enemy base and retreat... the mini-map does not show enemy structures when you lose vision of their base.

Same behaviour with GPS satelite. 

Is this intended? 
If so **it might be helpful to at least get a marker/dot/flag on the mini-map meaning "enemy base found here"** (so you know the rough location).

Maybe I even kind of like it... :)

data.title: Renderer: Do not use (Pseudo-)Fullscreen when Debugger is attached.
data.body:
This Pr implements a check which forces the Renderer to run OpenRA in Window Mode when a Debugger is attached. This elimimnates also the problem that you cant switch back to the IDE when the IDE freezes the Process ( in such cases Windows user has to log out and re login.

The actions are the following:
- User is runnig OpenRA with attached Debugger (Visual studio, etc) = OpenRA is running in a Window
- User runs OpenRA without Debugger = The selected mode from settings will be used.

data.title: Optimized FindResources worse case scenario path finding
data.body:
This will help with simple cases like no resources on the map, but also more complex ones such as no resources left in path-able range on a large island maps:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/756669/9429313/2b8508f4-49cc-11e5-90a4-f11dd321371d.png)

The map was http://resource.openra.net/maps/2928/ and removed due to the unbearable late-game lag.

data.title: LoadScreen: Do not crash when Image or Text is not defined.
data.body:
This crash can be reproduced without this PR by commenting out the loading image entry and loading text entry in mod.yaml. In this case the Pr adds a fallback loading message.

IMO In this unexpected case it is better to display `Loading...` instead of crashing the game.

data.title: Poor projectile impact performance
data.body:
I noticed arbitrary lag spikes caused by projectiles.

On my notebook with i5-4210M (and presumably some throttling even in 'performance' mode) the `Bullet` effect (sometimes Missile, too, but less pronounced) occasionally eats up to 80 ms on RA's shellmap in performance mode (and much more, sometimes over 300(!)ms in balanced/power-saving mode).

And while far less of an issue there, even on my i5-2500 main rig the projectiles cause occasional 10-20ms spikes.
Their appearance seems to be quite random, so I wonder whether it's only some specific part of the code that causes this.

A while ago I tried to find the exact cause by disabling the ShouldExplode checks and some effects (contrail, trail) one by one, but none of those improved the situation significantly (if at all).

Those hiccups can be quite annoying on slower systems, so it would be nice if someone managed to track down and get rid of the cause.

Edit: It appears it's not the projectile itself, but the stuff happening on impact (warheads).

data.title: Improve pathfinder performance (paths may change)
data.body:
Depends on #9140.

Introduces two changes which improve pathfinder performance, but which can change the resulting paths. The changes should be minor and the new paths shouldn't be drastically different, but we should keep an eye out just in case.

Overall, these changes save ~18% in pathfinding time.

data.title: Improve pathfinder performance
data.body:
A number of commits intended to make the pathfinder faster by reducing small inefficiencies in the parts of the engine it relies on.

This PR should not affect the pathfinder output at all. For testing I recommend recording a replay on bleed and replaying it with this PR - there should be no desyncs unless I've messed up.

Overall, these changes save ~21% in pathfinding time.
